title: Welcome to New Class of RIA Buyers
text:
Text size

In recent years, smaller RIAs’ “decision to merge or sell ... has become far more complex as a new wave of mega-RIAs with ambitious expansion plans has created a whole new class of industry buyers,” RIAIntel writes.

The publication reviews the landscape of the mega-RIAs, including their growth strategies and service models. Many of the massive new RIAs under construction promise to solve a basic set of challenges. “They can help a firm monetize (i.e. cash out) after years of building a wealth management practice,” RIAIntel writes. “Or they can bring in fresh tools to help grow a base of clients, and managed assets.”

The article profiles several of these potential buyers, including Focus Financial Partners , Lovell Minnick Partners, and Emigrant Partners. Each firm has a slightly different approach.

For example, Focus Financial lays out a fairly mundane set of reasons for selling your practice. It offers to take the managerial aspects of running a business off an advisor or team’s plate, usually for a hefty slice of cash flows. This kind of basic straightforward approach may be just fine for some advisors.

Other massive RIA-focused aggregators offer more specific skill sets to help catalyze growth. Lovell Minnick Partners, for example, has been cobbling together a broad range of financial services firms, not just asset managers, in a bid to create an advanced toolset for advisors at its captive RIA firms.

-- John Kimelman
description: Big aggregators have shaken up the business of merging and acquiring.
